base: Gills deformed or contorted or branched to form large cavities, sometimes never exposed; spores not forcibly discharged, hence spore print not obtainable; found mostly in deserts and mountains
Podaxales & Allies
prime: Not as above; spores forcibly discharged, hence a spore print obtainable IF SPORES ARE BEING PRODUCED; gills exposed at maturity; common and widespread

base: Spore print white to buff, yellow, yellow-orange or lilac-tinged
prime: Spore print some other color (pinkish, salmon, yellow-brown, brown, rusty-orange, rusty-brown, chocolate-brown, purplish, greenish, black, etc)

base: Universal veil enveloping young specimens and forming a volva at base of stalk when it ruptures and/or leaving numerous remnants (warts or flat patches) on cap
Amanitaceae
prime: Neither volva nor warts present (but cap and stalk may have scales and fibrils)

base: Gills typically free and veil present; veil usually forming an annulus ring on stalk, or if not then stalk typically scaly or slimy below the veil
prime: Not as above; veil absent, or if present then gills normally attached to the stalk

base: Cap slimy or viscid when moist; stalk sometimes viscid also; gills tissue divergent (under the microscope); not common
Amanitaceae
prime: Cap dry or only slightly viscid when moist; stalk dry; gill tissue not divergent; common
Lepiotaceae

base: Gills decurrent and foldlike (at least when young), ie gills thick, blunt, shallow, and usually forked with cross-veins
see Cantharellaceae
prime: Not as above; gills usually platelike or bladelike

base: Gills and/or flesh exuding a latex (milk or juice) when broken; stalk typically more than 3mm thick; spores with amyloid warts or ridges
Russulaceae
prime: Not as above

base: Fruiting body brittle and rather rigid, the stalk snapping open cleanly like a piece of chalk (ie without fibrous context); cap usually plane to depressed at maturity; stalk typically at least 3mm thick; veil absent; usually but not always terrestrial; cap and stalk tissue typically containing nexts of sphaerocysts; spores with amyloid warts or ridges
Russulaceae
prime: Not with above features

base: Gills soft and clean, with a waxy appearance or texture; cap often brightly colored; stalk more or less central; usually terrestrial; basidia long and narrow (at least six times as long as the spores); spores smooth
Hygrophoraceae
prime: Not as above; gills not normally waxy; stalk central to lateral or absent; on ground or wood
'Tricholomataceae' (1986)

base: Spore print pinkish to flesh-colored, salmon, pinkish-cinnamon, or sordid reddish
prime: Spore print some shade of orange, brown (including cinnamon-brown), green, purple, gray, or black

base: Universal veil present, usually forming a saclike volva at base of stalk
Pluteaceae
prime: Not as above; volva typically absent

base: Gills typically free at maturity; growing on wood (but wood sometimes buried!) or sawdust or sometimes in lignin-rich humus; spores NOT angular
Pluteaceae
prime: Not as above

base: Odor strong (fishy or like cucumber) and stalk velvety or arising from an underground, often hollow 'tuber' or found on wood and fruiting body pinkish to yellow-orange with a reticulate (veined) cap surface; spores NOT angular; not common
'Tricholomataceae' (1986)
prime: Not as above; common

base: Spore print pale pinkish, pinkish-buff, or pinkish-cream; gills sometimes purple or purple-tinged when fresh; spores NOT angular
'Tricholomataceae' (1986)
prime: Spore print usually deeper in color (flesh-colored to sordid reddish, salmon, etc); gills not often purple; spores usually angular in end and/or side view

base: Usually growing in clusters; flesh fragile; spores NOT angular; not common, at least in the western states
Coprinaceae
prime: Not as above; spores typically angular in end and/or side view; very common and widely distributed
Entolomataceae

base: Spore print greenish to grayish-olive
prime: Not as above

base: Gills adnate to decurrent
Gomphidiaceae
prime: Gills free or only slightly attached

base: Gills blood-red to reddish to dark brown
Agaricaceae
prime: Gills white to dull greenish or grayish
Lepiotaceae

base: Spore print purple-brown to purple-gray, purple-black, smoky-gray, black, chocolate-brown, or deep brown
prime: Spore print rusty-orange to rusty-brown, cinnamon-brown, yellow-brown, dull brown, bright brown, cigar-brown, etc (but may appear darker in heavy deposits!)

base: Gills usually decurrent (but sometimes adnate); spore print smoky-olive to smoky-gray to black; associated with conifers
Gomphidiaceae
prime: Not as above; gills free to adnexed, adnate or occasionally decurrent

base: Gills and/or cap auto-digesting (ie turning into inky black mass) at maturity; spore print black
Coprinaceae
prime: Not as above

base: Veil present, usually forming an annulus ring on stalk; gills free or nearly free at maturity, whitish to pinkish when young but becoming chocolate-brown or darker in age; cap NOT deeply striate; spore print chocolate-brown
Agaricaceae
prime: Not as above

base: Cap brightly colored (yellow, gre, orange, red, etc)
Strophariaceae
prime: Cap dull (some shade of brown, buff, gray, white, etc)

base: Gills decurrent; cap margin inrolled when young; spore print reddish-brown or cocoa-brown
Paxillaceae
prime: Not as above

base: Cap usually viscid when moist (but may dry out!!); fruiting body fragile or not fragile; cap cuticle typically filamentous (under microscope)
Strophariaceae
prime: Cap usually not viscid; fruiting body quite fragile; cap cuticle typically cellular (p.19)
Coprinaceae

base: Growing on other mushrooms
'Tricholomataceae' (1986)
prime: Not as above

base: Stalk absent or rudimentary; usually growing shelflike on wood
prime: Stalk present; on wood or ground

base: Fruiting body very tough, leathery or corky
Polyporaceae & Allies
prime: Not as above; fruiting body fleshy

base: Gills forked or with cross-veins or even pores near base of cap
Paxillaceae
prime: Not as above
Cortinariaceae

base: Fruiting body small, fragile, often withering quickly; cap usually oval to conical or bell-shaped; usually growing in grass, dung, or gardens; cap cuticle typically cellular (p.19)
Bolbitiaceae
prime: Not with above features

base: Gills typically decurrent, often forked (or even forming pores near stalk) and often peelig easily from cap; margin of caop usually inrolled when young; veil absent; spore print yellowish ot brown; stalk fleshy
Paxillaceae
prime: Not as above; gills occasionally decurrent but usually not; veil present or absent; spore print variously colored (rusty-orange, rusty-brown, dull brown, etc); very common
Cortinariaceae

base: Fruiting body medium-sized to very large, hard (especially the stalk); cap white to brown, black, or grayish (never brightly colored); gills typically adnate to decurrent and usually alternating long and short; cap cuticle (skin) NOT peeling easily, margin NOT striate
prime: Not with above combination of characteristics

base: Fruiting body basically white (but often with brown to yellowish stains); flesh and stalk surface NOT staining when bruised or cut
prime: Flesh and stalk surface changing color when bruised (within 10 minutes) and/or fruiting body not white

base: Cap 5-10cm broad; taste very acrid; gills and stalk never blue-green
Russula cascadensis
prime: Cap 7-20cm or more broad; taste mild to slightly acrid, or if distinctly acrid then gills and/or stalk apex usually tinged blue-green or green
Russula brevipes & others

base: Fruiting body turning dark grey to black DIRECTLY when bruised (within 5-10m), without an intermediate reddish phase; fruiting body blackening in age
Russula albonigra
prime: Not as above; if staining black, then with a preliminary reddish phase

base: Flesh and stalk surface distinctly staining reddish to orange when scratched or bruised (within 5m), then eventually darkening to dark gray, dark brownish-gray or black
prime: Not as above (but may stain reddish WITHOUT blackening afterward or may stain smoky-brown DIRECTLY)

base: Gills thick and widely spaced
Russula nigricans
prime: Not as above

base: Cap viscid when moist; taste usually acrid
Russula densifolia
prime: Cap not viscid; taste typically mild
Russula dissimulans

base: Gills usually with sordid reddish stains, often entirely reddish in old age; fruiting body NOT blackening; associated with oak in California and southern US
Russula subnigricans
prime: Not as above

base: Flesh typically staining faintly reddish when cut (within 20m), and then eventually pale smoky-brown (or at times without reddish phase)
Russula adusta
prime: Not as above

base: Fruiting body very firm and stalk hard; cap whitish becoming ochre, rusty-brown, or reddish-brown, margin NOT striate; all parts bruising or discoloring ochraceous to cinnamon-brown; odor often unpleasant in age, never sweet; spore print white; common in Eastern NA
Russula compacta
prime: Not as above

base: Odor heavy and sweet (like maraschino cherries or benzaldehyde), but in age often becoming fetid; cap medium-sized to large (5-15cm broad), yellow-brown to straw-color, dull ochre, or yellow-orange
Russula fragrantissima group
prime: Not as above

base: Cap 5-12cm broad, typically dark red with a nearly blackish center; taste usually acrid but sometimes mild; spore print whitish; common under hardwoods in eastern NA
Russula atropurpurea
prime: Not as above

base: Flesh and stalk surface staining grey to ashy or black (sometimes slowly and sometimes with an intermediate reddish phase
prime: Not as above

base: Cap yellow to ochre
prime: Cap orange to red, coppery, purple-red, etc (sometimes mixed with yellow)

base: Taste mild
Russula claroflava
prime: Taste acrid
Russula ochroleuca

base: Cap red to orange or coppery-brown; flesh bruising gray directly
Russula decolorans
prime: Cap purplish, greenish, brownish, etc. (often a mixture of colors); flesh usually turning reddish before graying
Russula occidentalis & others

base: Cap bright yellow to golden-yellow; mature gills yellowish
Russula lutea
prime: Not as above

base: Cap white or whitish to yellowish-white or pale yellow
prime: Cap some other color (including yellow-brown) when fresh, but may fade to whitish in age

base: Cap cuticle (skin) thick and rubbery
Russula crassotunicata
prime: Not as above

base: Spore print and gills white or whitish
prime: Spore print and mature gills yellowish

base: Cap pale yellow to yellowish-white, viscid when moist, the margin usually striage in age; taste acrid; usually scattered to gregarious
Russula cremoricolor and others
prime: Cap dull white or tinged buff or pink at center, often dirty, viscid or dry; taste mild or acrid; usually occurring in small numbers
Russula albidula group

base: Stalk typically staining yellow and then brown when scratched; odor fishy in age
Russula sp. unidentified (see R. xerampelina)
prime: Not as above
Russula maculata group

base: Taste of flesh AND/OR gills distinctly acrid (taste both!)
prime: Taste mild or nearly so

base: Stalk white (but sometimes with stains or discolorations, especially at base)
prime: Stalk red or flushed pink to rose

base: Cap yellow-brown to dull straw-color, hazel-brown, grayish-brown, or even darker at center; margin striate and with small bumps, at least in age; odor usually rather unpleasant; very common
Russula sororia group
prime: Not as above

base: Spore print and gills white or whitish
prime: Spore print yellow to ochre; gills yellowish at least in age
Russula alutacea & R. maculata group (JAR)

base: Stalk and flesh often slowly staining orange or pink when bruised (sometimes with an intermediate yellowish phase); cap typically multicolored (usually yellowish at center and splotched with yellow, orange, or red towards margin
Russula bicolor
prime: Not as above

base: Cap red suffused with gray or brown; associated with western conifers and especially common in the Rocky Mountains
Russula montana
prime: Not as above (but cap may be bright red)

base: Cap bright red when fresh, but often fading to pink, orange, or sometimes even white
Russula emetica group
prime: Not as above; cap variously colored but not bright red

base: Many gills forked at quite a distance from the stalk; stalk firm, 1-3cm thick, cap 5-15cm broad
Russula variata
prime: Gills not forked, or forked only near stalk; stalk usually less than 1.5cm thick, often quite fragile; cap up to 7cm broad
Russula fragilis & others

base: Stalk red to pink; cap dark red to bright red (but often fading in age)
Russula rosacea
prime: Cap pink, olive-gray, etc. or a mixture of these colors; stalk usually tinged rose or grayish-rose
Russula gracilis group

base: Cap surface dry and soon areolate (cracked into scales/plaques), greenish to blue-gray or with buff, yellowish, or even brownish tones; common under hardwoods in eastern US
prime: Not as above

base: Cap usually greenish or greenish-gray
Russula virescens
prime: Cap buff to yellowish or brownish, with green tones sometimes present also
Russula crustosa & others

base: Cap predominantly greenish or grayish-green (sometimes mixed with other colors); stalk white or whitish (or sometimes brownish-stained, but never pink); odor NOT fishy in age; spore print white to creamy (pale yellow), NOT ochre or dark yellow
prime: Not with above combination of characteristics; cap may have greenish tones, but typically the greenish tones not predominating

base: Spore print white; fruiting body often robust (stalk 1.5-3cm thick or more); stalk NOT staining salmon in ferrous sulfate
Russula cyanoxantha
prime: Spore print pale cream; stalk typically 0.7-2.5 cm thick, staining salmon in ferrous sulfate

base: Cap bluish-green to greenish, with a matte appearance
Russula parazurea
prime: Cap greenish to grayish, often with yellowish, rusty or brownish areas, and viscid when moist

base: Cap usually greenish; found with aspen, birch, oak and conifers
Russula aeruginea
prime: Cap often with other colors [than greenish]; found with oak and beech
Russula grisea

base: Cap small to medium-sized (2-7cm broad); surface dry, reddish to purple, but overlaid with a fine whitish powder or velvety bloom
Russula mariae
prime: Not as above; cap lacking whitish bloom

base: Spore print and gills white or whitish
prime: Spore print yellow to ochre; gills yellowish in age

base: Cap typically with purplish, pinkish-lilac, bluish, and/or yellow tones; fruiting body sometimes large; gills often slightly greasy to the touch; stalk NOT staining salmon in ferrous sulfate
Russula cyanoxantha
prime: Cap usually browner, grayer, redder, or more flesh-colored than above; fruiting body usually medium-sized; stalk staining salmon in ferrous sulfate

base: Predominant color of cap typically flesh-color or reddish; cuticle (skin) often wrinkled; found mainly in eastern NA
Russula vesca
prime: Predominant color of cap typically some shade of brown, olive-brown, gray, or gray-brown; widespread
Russula brunneola

base: Stalk typically staining yellow when scratched, then slowly becoming brownish; stalk usually rose-colored or at least with a blush of pink, but white in some forms; fruiting body medium-sized to very large; odor shrimpy or fishy in old age
Russula xerampelina
prime: Not as above

base: Cap red to pink, orange, or whitish, or a mixture of these colors; associated with hardwoods, especially oak; stalk white
Russula maculata group
prime: Not as above

base: Cap 2-6cm broad, markedly fragile, variously colored but usually with at least some purple
Russula placita group & others
prime: Not as above; larger ad/or not markedly fragile

base: Cap large, firm, sometimes massive (up to 35cm broad!); stalk often tinged pinkish
Russula olivacea
prime: Not as above; mediums-sized to fairly large, but not massive; stalk usually white

base: Spores and mature gills creamy; found with hardwoods
Russula grisea
prime: Spores and mature gills yellow to ochre; found with hardwoods or conifers

base: Cap medium-sized (3-12cm broad), burgundy to livid red, purple, or rusty-red, or with a brownish center, or with reddish-buff tones; fruiting body quite firm
Russula integra
prime: Not as above; medium-sized to fairly large (cap 5-20cm broad) and often fragile in old age
Russula alutacea group

base: Fruiting body whitisih except for yellow to golden-orange powder, flakes, or granules on the cap and/or stalk apex (but powder may smear in wet weather)
Hygrophorus chrysodon
prime: Not as above (if fruiting body white, then lacking yellow to golden-orange granules

base: Fruiting body white to creamy, buff, or pale yellow when fresh
prime: Fruiting body at least partially darker or differently colored (including bright lemon-yellow)

base: Stalk viscid or slimy when moist, at least over lower portion
prime: Stalk not viscid

base: Cap tinged buff to yellowish or pale yellow, at least at center; especially common under pine (but not restricted to it)
Hygrophorus gliocyclus & others
prime: Not as above

base: Stalk usually at least 1.5cm thick; cap fairly large (5-15cm broad)
Hygrophorus ponderatus
prime: Stalk usually (but not always) less than 1.5cm thick; cap medium-sized to fairly small

base: Cap conical when young, usually with a prominent umbo in age; gills NOT decurrent; found in eastern NA, rarely in California (mostly under cypress)
Hygrophorus pura
prime: Not as above; gills adnate to decurrent; widespread
Hygrophorus eburneus

base: Cap NOT conical; stalk 1-7cm thick, or if thinner than cap viscid when moist and developing distinct yellow-brown to reddish-brown, peachy, salmon, or ochre tones in age
prime: Not as above; stalk typically less than 1cm thick and/or cap distinctly conical

base: Stal often with an annulus ring or 'volva' that is easily obliterated; typically found under mountain conifers
Hygrophorus subalpinus
prime: Not as above; annulus or 'volva' absent

base: Fruiting body white or discoloring slightly yellowish or buff; associated mainly with oak, occasionally with conifers
Hygrophorus sordidus & others
prime: Either fruiting body discoloring more dramatically in age or else associated with conifers and possessing a densely scurfy stalk and apex

base: Growing in grass; stalk tough and pliant; cap often umbonate
Marasmius oreades
prime: Not as above

base: Odor sharp and cedarlike or fragrant
Camarophyllus russocoriaceus
prime: Odor mild or not distinctive (or merely fungal)

base: Cap conical when young and/or gills typically notched or adnexed or at times adnate; gill hyphae parallel
Hygrocybe subaustraliga & Hygrocybe albinella
prime: Cap not normally conical; gills typically adnate to decurrent; gill hyphae not parallel

base: Cap viscid when moist
prime: Cap not viscid

base: Cap thin and often translucent-striate when moist, usually less than 3cm broad; found in many habitats; gill tissue interwoven
Camarophyllus niveus
prime: Not as above; found mainly under conifers; gill tissue divergent
Hygrophorus piceae

base: Growing in groups or troops on pine needles; gills very widely spaced and usually with veins in between; cap broadly convex soon becoming plane or umbilicate
Merasmius sp.(unidentified)
prime: Not as above

base: Fruiting body often developing a slightly yellowish tinge in age; cap dry
Camarophyllus virgineus
prime: Not as above; cap sometimes slightly lubricous
Camarophyllus borealis

base: Cap small (up to 6cm broad but usually less), dry, honey-colored or yellowish to orange or scarlet beneath a layer of small, gray to dark brwon or blackish fibrillose scales
prime: Not as above; either cap viscid or larger or lacking dark scales or differently colored

base: Background of cap scarlet to orange when fresh
Hygrocybe turunda
prime: Background of cap buff to dull yellowish or honey-colored; found in eastern NA
Hygrocybe caespitosa

base: Fruiting body staining gray to black when handled (often slowly); cap conical, at least when young; common
Hygrocybe conica
prime: Not as above; fruiting body not blackening when handled

base: Cap bright red, yellow, orange or at least when fresh (but may fade to whitish)
prime: Cap some other color(including pink, salmon, vinaceous, purple-red, pale dull orange, etc)

base: Cap and lower portion of stalk viscid to slimy when moist; stalk typically 4mm thick or more and NOT hollow; gills adnate to decurrent; gill tissue divergent
prime: Not as above; if both cap and stalk viscid, then stalk typically slender, hollow and fragile

base: Cap red to orange when young at least at center
Hygrophorus speciosus
prime: Cap at first dark brown to olive-brown to center, the brighter colors developing in age and the center often remaining brownish
Hygrophorus hypothejus

base: Cap dark to bright red when fresh (but may fade in age or as it dries to orange or yellow)
prime: Cap orange to yellow (sometimes fading to whitish), never bright red

base: Cap conical, up to 5cm broad, bright red and not usually fading, viscid when moist; stalk also red and usually viscid; found in eastern NA
Hygrocybe ruber
prime: Not as above

base: Cap AND stalk distinctly viscid to slimy when moist; cap usually small or minute
Hygrocybe reai & others
prime: Not as above

base: Cap distinctly conical when young and usually retaining a pointed umbo in age; stalk yellow
Hygrocybe cuspidata
prime: Not as above

base: Gills usually distinctly decurrent; cap typically small or minute (less than 4cm broad)
prime: Not as above

base: Cap small (1-4cm), NOT viscid, red to scarlet when moist but fading drastically as it dries to orange or even yellow
Hygrocybe miniata
prime: Not as above (if cap not viscid, then cap not fading drastically or cap larger)

base: Stalk white (base may be colored)
Hygrocybe laetissima
prime: Stalk yellow to orange or red

base: Cap viscid when moist; stalk typically 1-2cm thick
Hygrocybe punicea & others
prime: Cap not viscid or only slightly viscid; stalk typically 3-8mm thick, usually red to reddish-orange with a yellow to orange base
Hygrocybe coccinea & others

base: Cap and stalk slimy or very viscid when moist; cap generall 4cm broad or less
prime: Not as above (cap may be slimy, but stalk dry to only slightly viscid)

base: Fruiting body showing pink, flesh-colored or greenish (rarely bluish) tones somewhere on fruiting body; gills not normally decurrent
Hygrocybe psittacina
prime: Not as above; fruiting body yellow to orange (but may show some white or have a lilac tinge)

base: Growing on rotting conifers
Mycena lilacifolia
prime: Not as above; usually growing on the ground

base: Gills typically decurrent AND cap usually depressed centrally
Hygrocybe nitida
prime: Not as above
Hygrocybe chlorophana & others

base: Cap distinctly viscid or slimy when moist, 2-7cm broad or more when expanded; gills not decurrent
prime: Cap not viscid, or if slightly viscid then less than 3cm broad or gills decurrent

base: Cap distinctly conical, at least when young
Hygrocybe autoconica
prime: Cap broadly convex to plane, not conical
Hygrocybe flavescens & others

base: Gills brilliant orange to yellow-orange, retaining their color even after the cap fades; common in eastern NA, occasional in Pacific NW
Hygrocybe marginata
prime: Not as above; common and widespread

base: Gills usually not decurrent; cap red to orange-red when fresh and moist (but fading)
Hygrocybe miiata & others
prime: Not as above; gills usually decurrent

base: Found in humus; cap yellow to orange-yellow (never scarlet, red, or orange)
Hygrocybe parvula & others
prime: Not as above

base: Stalk usually quite long (4-10cm); found mainly in eastern NA on ground, in moss, or on rotten wood
Hygrocybe cantharellus
prime: Not as above; found on ground, or if in lichen, moss or wood, then stalk not so long

base: Typically found in humus or soil; cap red or scarlet when fresh
Hygrocybe subminiata
prime: Not as above; often found on wood, lichens, moss
see Omphalina & Xeromphalina

base: Cap sharply conical when young, usually retaining a pointed umbo in age, coral-pink to pink, pinkish-orange or salmon; gills pink
Hygrocybe calyptraeformis
prime: Not as above

base: Entire stalk or at least the lower part distinctly viscid to slimy WHEN MOIST; cap also viscid
prime: Stalk dry to slightly lubricous but not viscid; cap dry or viscid

base: Cap small; stalk slender (usually less than 6mm thick), hollow, NOT white; veil absent
prime: Cap usually medium-sized to fairly large; stalk typically at least 5mm thick, sometimes white; veil present or absent

base: Cap blackish to dark brown or grayish
Hygrocybe unguinosa
prime: Not as above; cap brighter or lighter in color

base: Cap sometimes green or greenish-tinged; gills typically adnate
Hygrocybe psittacina
prime: Green shades absent; gills often decurrent
Hygrocybe laeta

base: Cap dull yellowish becoming browner or grayer in age; stalk at least 1cm thick; gills white or developing greenish stains, but not yellow; found mainly under hardwoods in eastern NA
Hygrophorus paludosus
prime: Not as above

base: Cap (or center of cap) chestnut-brown to cinnamon-brown, reddish-brown, pinkish-tan, salmon, or yellow-brown
prime: Cap olive-brown to grayish-brown, gray, blackish, etc

base: Cap and gills rufous to rusty-orange, apricot, or salmon-buff; growing under oaks in eastern NA
Hygrophorus subsalmonius
prime: Not as above

base: Odor fragrant, like almond extract
Hygrophorus variicolor
prime: Odor more or less mild
Hygrophorus laurae & others

base: Lower portion of stalk sheathedw with gray to brown, olive-brown, or blackish fibrils or scales, or granules; cap, gills, or stalk NOT yellow
Hygrophorus olivaceoalbus & others
prime: Not as above

base: Gills creamy to yellow or orange; cap and stalk often exhibiting some yellow or orange tones
Hygrophorus hypothejus
prime: Yellow and orange tones absent

base: Cap evenly blackish to deep olive-brown when young; found mainly in eastern NA
Hygrophorus fuligineus
prime: Cap paler when young or with a paler margin; widespread
Hygrophorus fuscoalbus & others

base: Gills persistently bright orange to yellow-orange, even after cap fades; cap 1-5cm broad, stalk less than 6mm thick
Hygrocybe marginata
prime: Not as above

base: Cap green (citrine-green), at least when mature
Hygrocybe virescens
prime: Not as above

base: Cap gray to grayish-brown, dark grayish-brown, olive, deep olive-brown, blackish or umber; gills and cap lacking violet or blue tones
prime: Cap differently colored (tan, reddish-brown, vinaceous, etc), or if colored as above then cap or gills with a violet, lilac, or bluish tinge when fresh

base: Cap conical or with a pointed umbo, dull or dark gray
Hygrocybe acuta (see Camarophyllus recurvatus)
prime: Not as above

base: Odor fragrant (like almond extract), but sometimes faint
Hygrophorus agathosmus & others
prime: Odor mild or not as above

base: Base of stalk usually pale pinkish to pinkish-orange (especially interior)
see Tricholoma saponaceum
prime: Not as above

base: Stalk sheathed by grayish to dark grayish-brown fibrils, scales, or granules
Hygrophorus inocybiformis
prime: Not as above

base: Fruiting body rather small (cap typically less than 5cm broad, stalk typically less than 1cm thick and sometimes hollow)
Camarophyllus recurvatus & others
prime: Not as above; fruiting body medium-sized; stalk usually 1cm thick or more

base: Cap viscid to slimy when moist; gills white or pink
Hygrophorus calophyllus
prime: Cap viscid or dry, often appearing streaked; gills white or gray
Hygrophorus camarophyllus & others

base: Stalk rooting deeply or with a 'taproot' encased by grayish-brown volva-like material; cap white becoming pinkish to vinaceous-red; gills whilte; known only from southern California under oak; solitary or clustered
Hygrophorus marianae
prime: Not as above; widespread and common

base: Gills (or entire fruiting body) soon streaked or stained coral-red to vinaceous, pinkish-red, or purple-red (especially in age), sometimes also with yellow stains
prime: Not as above (but gills may be naturally pinkish)

base: Associated with hardwoods (mainly oak and tanoak)
Hygrophorus russula
prime: Associated with conifers (mainly pine and spruce)

base: Cap reddish at first but staining yellow and becoming pale to bright yellow in age; taste bitter; especially common in the Rockies
Hygrophorus amarus (see H. purpurascens)
prime: Not as above (but fruiting body may yellow somehwat); widespread (including Rockies)

base: Fibrillose veil present, at least when young
Hygrophorus purpurascens
prime: Veil absent
Hygrophorus erubescens & H. capreolarius (see H. purpurascens)

base: Gills lilac or violet or pinkish to dingy flesh-colored, attached and sometimes slightly decurrent but not DEEPLY decurrent; stalk tough and fibrous, pliant, often fibrillose; cap often minutely scaly or scurfy, NOT viscid; spores usually spiny
see Laccaria
prime: Not as above; spores smooth

base: Gills and/or cap with a violet, purple, or bluish tinge when fresh
Camarophyllus subviolaceus & others
prime: Not as above

base: Gills brown to vinaceous-brown, adnate to decurrent; cap some shade of brown when moist, fading as it dries; found with hardwoods in eastern NA
Hygrophorus kauffmanii
prime: Not as above; gills paler

base: Growing in grass; cap buff to tan, often umbonate; gills whitish; stalk thin, tough, pliant
see Marasmius oreades
prime: Not as above

base: Cap 4.5cm broad or less, translucent-striate when moist
prime: Not as above; cap typically opaque

base: Stalk 4-7mm thick; cap vinaceous-brown to pinkish-gray or buff, slightly viscid when moist; gills pinkish-gray or paler, distinctly decurrent; terrestrial
Camarophyllus colemannianus
prime: Not as above; growing on ground or wood
see Tricholomataceae

base: Stalk 1-3cm thick, the apex distinctly scurfy (punctate); cap 5-20cm broad, pale tan to pinkish, flesh-colored, pinkish-orange, or occasionally whitish; gills usually tinged pink (but sometimes whitish); cap viscid when moist, the margin inrolled until maturity; odor NOT like almond extract; associated with conifers (especially spruce)
Hygrophorus pudorinus
prime: Not with above combination of characteristics

base: Gills distinctly paler than center of cap (white to creamy or pale yellow)
prime: Gills colored like the cap or slightly paler or darker (pinkish to salmon, etc)

base: Odor faintly fragrant (like almond extract) to strongly aromatic
prime: Not as above; odor usually mild or somewhat potato-like

base: Odor like almond extract
Hygrophorus bakerensis & others
prime: Odor strongly aromatic (but not as above)
Hygrophorus pacificus (see H. bakerensis)

base: Cap pink or rose (but may fade!), stalk lacking sordid yellowish patches below; found under mountain conifers, often near melting snow
Hygrophorus goetzii
prime: Not with above features
Hygrophorus roseibrunneus

base: Odor sickeningly sweet; fruiting body pinkish-buff to pinkish-cinnamon; cap not viscid
Camarophyllus graveolens
prime: Not as above

base: Cap whitish to buff, sometimes with darker spots or zones; odor often faintly fruity (if kept in a closd space); gills pinkish-cinnamon to salmon or ochre-salmon; associated with conifers (but not redwood); gill hyphae divergent
Hygrophorus saxatilis
prime: Not with above features

base: Cap whitish when young
Hygrophorus albicastaneus & others
prime: Cap not white when young (but may be quite pale in age or after fading)

base: Gills adnexed to adnate or slightly decurrent; stalk 1-4cm thick, cap 5-13cm broad; odor mild or radish- to cucumberlike; gill hyphae divergent; usually associated with oak
Hygrophorus nemoreus
prime: Not as above; gills usually decurrent
Camarophyllus pratensis

base: Volva present at base of stalk as a sack, fre collar, or series of concentric rings
Amanita
prime: Volva absent or indistinct

base: Cap usually viscid or slimy when moist, without warts or veil material; stalk sometimes slimy also
Limacella
prime: Cap usually wit warts or universal veil material, often dry or slightly viscid but not usually slimy; stalk never slimy
Amanita

base: Volva saclike (ie forming a true sack that sheathes the base of the stalk); cap usually bald or with a cottony or membranous patch of universal veil tissue or occasionally with several patches or non-friable warts
prime: Volva collarlike (ie intergrown with base of stalk but with a free rim), scaly, warty, powdery, or indistinct but NOT saclike; cap often with many small pieces of universal veil tissue warts, powder, etc., occasionally with larger pieces

base: Volva tough, thick, large; cap and/or stalk often shaggy, fibrillose, or with cottony patches of veil tissue; cap white or tinged brown (especially at center), often bruising brown or reddish, margin often striate in age; stalk similarly colored; annulus ring absent; spores oblong or elliptical, amyloid; farily common in eastern NA, rare in West
Amanita volvata
prime: Not with above features

base: Margin of cap distinctly striate (at least when mature); spores NOT amyloid
prime: Margin of cap not striate or only faintly so (occasionally striate in age); spores amyloid

base: Partial veil present when young, usually (but not always!) forming an annulus ring on stalk
prime: Partial veil and annulus ring absent or rudimentary (but stalk sometimes scaly)

base: Gils and stalk yellow to yellow-orange; cap bright red to orange (but may fade to yellow or paler in age or sunlight
Amanita caesarea group & others
prime: Not as above; gills and stalk typically white to creamy or very pale yellow

base: Volva often small and inconspicuous; cap brown to gray or sometimes nearly white; growing in mixed woods and under hardwoods in eastern NA
Amanita spreta
prime: Not as above; known only from western NA

base: Cap brown to yellowish or whitish, but if brown then usually with a yellow margin; partial veil typically (but not always!) forming a prominent skirtlike annulus on stalk
Amanita calyptrata
prime: Cap variously colored, but the margin not yellow; annulus ring usually pressed closely to the stalk or poorly defined

base: Cap dark brown to gray or grayish-brown
prime: Cap white to pale tan, beige, orangish, pinkish, orange-brown, or reddish-brown

base: Fruiting body medium-sized to large; cap dary gray to dark brown when young, often paler in age and often developing a darker band near inner edge of striations; gill edges usually brown; known only from teh West
Amanita pachycolea
prime: Fruiting body medium-sized to rather small and slender; cap usually gray, but sometimes grayish-brown or brown; gill edges not brown; widely distributed

base: Cap white with long striations; widespread but rare in West
Amanita alba
prime: Not as above; if cap white then with shorter striations and usually found near western oaks in winter and spring (or even summer); common

base: Cap pinkish-tan to orangish, beige, or paler
Amanita velosa & others
prime: Cap orange-brown to reddish-brown, tawny, etc; common in eastern NA, infrequent in West
Amanita fulva

base: Cap greenish to yellow-green, brownish-olive, grayish-olive, or nearly white when young, often duller (dingy tan, etc) or with a metallic luster in age
Amanita phalloides
prime: Not as above; cap usually white or whitish when fresh (but may discolor by maturity)

base: Cap white, but discoloring pinkish, brownish, or yellowish (at least centrally) in age; associated with oak; found in California and the Southwest and Texas
Amanita ocreata
prime: Cap usually remaining white or found elsewhere

base: Cap white; partial veil usually forming a distinct annulus ring on stalk (which may disappear in age!); very common in eastern NA, also found in PNW
Amanita virosa & others
prime: Not as above; partial veil absent or evanescent; found in eastern NA
Amanita peckiana & others

base: Universal veil remnants yellow to grayish-yellow (check cap for warts and base of stalk for volva); cap NOT whitish
prime: Universal veil remnants not yellow; cap may or may not be whitish

base: Partial veil absent; gills yellow; found in eastern NA
Amanita parcivolvata
prime: Not as above

base: Cap bright red to orange-red (but may fade in age); stalk white
Amanita muscaria
prime: Cap orange to yellow-brown or dark brown; stalk white or yellow

base: Lower stalk sheathed with shaggy scales
see Armillaria & Allies
prime: Not as above

base: Cap salmon to salmon-pink when fresh; found in mountains of eastern US
Amanita wellsii
prime: Not as above

base: Base of stalk staining reddish in age or where bruised; found in eastern NA
Amanita flavorubescens
prime: Not with above features (if staining as above, then found in West)

base: Cap yellow to yellow-brown to dark brown; stalk usually white; common along the Pacific Coast
Amanita aspera
prime: Cap yellow-orange to yellow; stalk often colored similarly; fruiting body rather small; coimmon in eastern NA, rare in West
Amanita flavoconia

base: Cap pale yellow-green to pale yellow to nearly whitish with thin grayish, whitish-buff, or pinkish to lavender-gray warts (which may wash off); cap margin NOT striate; stalk with an abrupt, soft, rounded bulb at base; spores amyloid; common in eastern NA, especially under hardwoods but also with conifers
Amanita citrina
prime: Not as above

base: Cap brown to olive-brown or paler; stalk lacking grayish patches, terminating in an abrupt basal bulb that is usually split or chiseled longitudinally; flesh usualy staining reddish-brown; spores amyloid; common in eastern NA (especially under hardwoods); also reported from PNW (but rare)
Amanita brunnescens
prime: Not as above

base: Cap brightly colored (red, orange, or yellow); partial veil present, usually forming an annulus ring on stalk
prime: Not as above (cap may be sordid reddish or reddish-brown, pinkish-tan, etc)

base: Volva usually a series of concentric rings at apex of bulbous stalk base, but sometimes only a single ring or collar; cap medium-sized to large and bright red to orange, apricot, yellow-orange, or yellow (yellow rare form in coastal California but common in Sierra Nevada and most of eastern NA)
Amanita muscaria
prime: Volva usually a single collar at top of basal bulb or often indistinct, but sometimes consisting of several rings; cap small to medium-sized (occasionally large), usually pale yellow (but sometimes brighter), at times completely covered by veil material; widespread
Amanita gemmata

base: Partial veil absent (check young speciments if possible); cap margin distinctly striate; spores not amyloid
prime: Partial veil present, or if absent, then cap margin NOT striate; spores amyloid or not

base: Cap gray to grayish-brown, brown, or darker
prime: Cap pale yellow, orange-buff, salmon, pinkish, tan, or nearly white

base: Cap powdery-mealy; volva if present also mealy
Amanita farinosa
prime: Not as above

base: Cap gray or sometimes grayish-brown, with or without warts; upper limb of volva usually well-developed (but falls off easily); common in California
Amanita constricta
prime: Cap gray to brown to dark brown to nearly black, usually with warts; upper limb of volva not well-developed; widespread but rare in California
Amanita inaurata

base: Cap yellow to creamy whitish; volva usually collarlike (with free rim)
Amanita gemmata
prime: Cap orange-buff to pale pinkish-orange to pinkish-tan, beige, or sometimes whitish; volva not typically collarlike; often growing in the open (but near trees)
Amanita velosa

base: Cap entirely brown when young, breaking up into large brown scales in age; flesh in stalk usually staining orange or saffron (and eventually reddish) when cut
see Lepiota rachodes
prime: Not as above

base: Cap with erect, often pyramidal brown warts which usually come off easily; stalk and/or underside of veil with similar warts; spores usually dextrinoid, NOT amyloid
see Lepiota
prime: Not with above features (but may have some of them); common

base: Some part of fruiting body usually with sordid reddish stains (especially the stalk); flesh SLOWLY staining dingy reddish when bruised or cut; maggot tunnels also reddish
Amanita rubescens
prime: Not as above

base: Fresh fruiting body white or whitish (but may age buff, yellowish, brownish, pinkish, etc)
prime: Not as above; cap distinctly colored or with colored veil material even when young

base: Stalk terminating in a fairly conspicuous bulb, NOT typically with a rooting portion below the bulb
prime: Stalk without bulb, or if with a bulb, then also with a tapered rooting base below the bulb

base: Volva typically present as a distinct free rim or series of concentric rings at apex of basal bulb; spores NOT amyloid
prime: Not as above; spores amyloid

base: Volva typically consisting of a single tight-fitting collar around the bulb apex; cap often tinged yellowish or brownish at center; often rather slender
Amanita cothurnata
prime: Volva usually a series of concentric rings; cap white to grayish-white or tinged buff; not unusually slender
Amanita muscaria

base: Cap surface with a rather soft and cottony universal veil tissue, lacking conspicuous warts; known only from western NA
Amanita silvicola
prime: Not as above (if cap cottony, then found elsewhere)

base: Cap usually with brown warts; stalk often rather stout (up to 8cm long); known only from California; associated with live oak
Amanita sp. (unidentified); see A. rubescens
prime: Not as above

base: Cap without warts or warts obscure; growing in sand
Amanita baccata
prime: Not as above; cap usually with distinct, well-developed warts

base: Cap covered with large, exaggerated warts; fairly common with oak and pine, known only from California
Amanita magniverrucata
prime: Found elsewhere, or if found in California then warts smaller and often concentrated at center of cap
Amanita cokeri & many others ('Lepidella')

base: Stalk arising from a well-developed cylindrical to jug-shaped, sometimes hollow, underground 'tuber'; rare
see Squamanita
prime: Not as above (but stalk may root deeply or have bulbous base)

base: Cap yellow to creamy, the margin usually striate or tuberculate-striate
prime: Not with above features

base: Volva indistinct, powdery, or scaly; cap margin not normally striate
prime: Volva usually present as a free rim or collar on basal bulb and/or margin of cap striate in age

base: Found in California
prime: Found in eastern NA (especially common in Southeast)

base: Usually found in open ground (pastures, etc); partial veil often disappearing; cap grayish-white to gray to brownish-gray; small
Amanita sp. (unidentified)
prime: Associated with oak; partial veil usually forming a persistent, prominent annulus ring; cap white to brownish
Amanita sp. (unidentified); see A. rubescens

base: Warts gray and/or stalk gray or with grayish patches; spores amyloid
Amanita porphyria
prime: Stalk white; warts usually white or pallid; spores not amyloid
Amanita pantherina

base: Cap brown
Amanita calyptroides (see A. calyptrata)
prime: Cap orangish to salmon, pinkish-tan, buff, or even whitish
Amanita velosa

base: Lower part of volva tightly constricted around stalk, the upper part flaring outward
Amanita constricta
prime: Not as above; volva saclike
Amanita vaginata

base: Cap pallid beneath a thin coating of pinkish-tan to brownish-orange universal veil material and often with several large chunky warts at center; found in woods in Southeast
Amanita roseitincta
prime: Not as above

base: Cap distinctly pinkish when fresh; usually found in open; southern
Amanita salmonea
prime: Not as above

base: Cap with concentrically arranged brown to grayish-brown universal veil remnants (scales); partial veil evanescent; known only from the Southeast
Amanita hesleri
prime: Not as above; cap usually grayish or with grayish warts

base: Cap pale brown to dark grayish-brown, with large grayish warts or patches; partial veil usually forming a distinct annulus ring on stalk
Amanita spissa (see A. pantherina)
prime: Not as above; cap grayish
Amanita onusta & A. cinereoconica
